required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: How the Habitats Created by MRI Can Predict the IDH Mutation Status and Prognosis of the Patients With High-grade Glioma
clinical_study.official_title: To Determine Whether the Habitats Created by the Preoperative Perfusion and Diffusion MRI Can Predict IDH Mutation Status and the Overall Survival of Patients With High-grade Glioma
clinical_study.source: Daping Hospital and the Research Institute of Surgery of the Third Military Medical University

brief_summary.textblock:
High-grade glioma is the most common primary malignant tumor in central nervous system, and its high tumor heterogeneity is the main cause of tumor progression, treatment resistance and recurrence. Habitat imaging is a segmentation technique by dividing tumor regions to characterize tumor heterogeneity based on tumor pathology, blood perfusion, molecular characteristics and other tumor biological features.
In some studies, the Hemodynamic Multiparametric Tissue Signature (HTS) method has been proven to be feasible. The Hemodynamic Multiparametric Tissue Signature (HTS) consists of a set of vascular habitats obtained by Dynamic Susceptibility Weighted Contrast Enhanced Magnetic Resonance Imaging (DSC-MRI) of high-grade gliomas using a multiparametric unsupervised analysis method. This allows us to automatically draw 4 reproducible habitats which enable to describe the tumor vascular heterogeneity:
1. The High Angiogenic enhancing Tumor (HAT)
2. The Less Angiogenic enhancing Tumor (LAT)
3. The potentially tumor Infiltrated Peripheral Edema (IPE)
4. The Vasogenic Peripheral Edema (VPE)
In other studies, contrast-enhancing mass can divided into spatial habitats by K-means clustering of voxel-wise apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) and cerebral blood volume (CBV) values.
To sum up, the assumption of this experiment is that the Habitats Created by The Hemodynamic Multiparametric Tissue Signature (HTS) and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) can predict isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation status and the overall survival of patients with high-grade glioma.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation between the overall survival time (in days) of the patients with high-grade glioma and the habitat created by perfusion and diffusion imaging
primary_outcome.time_frame: From the date of the first MRI acquisition until the date of death from any causeï¼Œassessed up to 90 months
primary_outcome.description: The overall survival for each patient is estimated since the date of the preoperative Magnetic Resonance Imaging to the end of recruitment. The overall survival will be confirmed through clinical follow-up.

study_pop.textblock: The subjects we selected are adults who are not restricted by gender. There have some inclusion criteria: (a) no prior history of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or corticosteroid treatment; (b) a histopathologic diagnosis of WHO grade-III gliomas and GBM according to the WHO criteria; (c) known IDH genotype; (d) access to preoperative MR imaging examinations, including perfusion imaging and diffusion imaging.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- (a) no prior history of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or corticosteroid treatment; (b) a histopathologic diagnosis of WHO grade-III gliomas and GBM according to the WHO criteria; (c) known IDH genotype; (d) access to preoperative MR imaging examinations, including perfusion imaging and diffusion imaging.
Exclusion Criteria:
- (a) poor quality images; (b) errors when processed with automatic pipeline (c) suffering from other intracranial tumors at the same time

link.description: Vascular habitat analysis based on dynamic susceptibility contrast perfusion MRI predicts IDH mutation status and prognosis in high-grade gliomas

reference.citation: Wu H, Tong H, Du X, Guo H, Ma Q, Zhang Y, Zhou X, Liu H, Wang S, Fang J, Zhang W. Vascular habitat analysis based on dynamic susceptibility contrast perfusion MRI predicts IDH mutation status and prognosis in high-grade gliomas. Eur Radiol. 2020 Jun;30(6):3254-3265. doi: 10.1007/s00330-020-06702-2. Epub 2020 Feb 20.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Daping Hospital and the Research Institute of Surgery of the Third Military Medical University
